About Style Guides and Conventions

Well this topic deserve a separate blog post on it’s own; so I I’ll start drafting it our here :):

Keeping everything “organized” was also my obsession (as well as many geeks, with similar mindsets, I believe :)).

I’ve realized that the more you learn to let things go, the more productive you become.

It’s true not only for style guides, but also for any kind of strict rule that you impose upon the way you do things.

I have realized (after 10 or so years) that it all boils down to consistency. Trying to come up with a writing style guide, or a coding style guide (for programming) is a futile effort. — There are so many variations (in both writing, and also coding) that you cannot cover all the bases.

Besides, there are already very good style guides out there; it’d be wiser to stick with them. And about punctuation and grammar, there are resources like…

  • the punctuation guide</li>
  • Grammarly Handbook
  • Grammar Girl
  • this little guide to grammar and writing
  • this little OWL
  • daily writing tips
  • and this grammar monster

In the end of the day, your writing is your style; it is — kind of — your “signature”. The more you write, the more consistent it will get. — And most of the guides listed abouve, are ”guidelines” as their name imply; they are recommendations because there cannot be one true way in writing.

The logical conclusion to that is documenting my style is useless, as it will gradually change. Even worse, by putting things on paper, I will be, unconsciously, preventing my style from changing, improving, growing, and developing.

The deeper you dive, the more conflicting rules you’ll come up with; so it’s better to keep it fluid, and try to be consistent on a broader level.

And, since it’s a signature, it’s useful for nobody but me; it’s so personal that it’s hard to document (can you geometrically define how to create an identical signature of yours? it’s the same with writing), and even if you manage to document it, it’s again so personal that it will be useful for nobody but me.

And obviously people have been pondering on these issus a lot, so why not follow their piece of mind, instead of reinventing the wheel?

So for code style idiomatic js, and I do it my own way if I disagree with anything in there.

Similarly, for writing, I follow the above links (in priority order) and do it my own way, if I disagree with them.
